YES, bikes AUTOSTEER, when leaned, to return to a vertical state (balanced).  Three forces cause the steer,  front tire weighting, caster effect and gyroscopic precession.  The "ghost bike" illustrates this.  If the bike is not allowed to autosteer, by locking down the steering head or rider forces the bike to steer opposite the lean direction, it falls down.  This illustrates why a bike cannot counter steer.  To turn, the rider simply overrides this feature by adding a specific amount of sideways torque (with HB leverage), for a specific turn size.

Too much credit is given to gyroscopic effect. It's negligible so to be insignificant on virtually all properly designed bicycles. Plus, some of today's road wheels are so ridiculously light, they have hardly any mass or gyro effect and the bikes with them ride perfectly fine.

Several physicists have made bicycles with two pairs of wheels sharing the same mass. The normal wheels support the bicycle, the secondary wheels mirror the front and rear and spin at the same speed in the opposite direction, thereby canceling out the gyroscopic effect. The bicycles ride perfectly normally.

Frame, fork, wheel design and application are responsible.

Alternatively, a physics professor designed a bicycle with incorrect steering angle, offset and trail so as to steer in the opposite direction as normal. Lean left, bike steers right. He let lecture attendees ride it. He said that at all the lectures he gave, very few people could actually ride the bike. And the few that did took several attempts. If the bike the scientist made has zero trail and the gyroscopic effect is nullified, then how does it balance? It is due to the cross-sectional shape of the tires. When a bike with rounded wheels (which they all have, including the 'science bike') leans, the rotational speed on the inside of the lean is slower than the outside~ within the contact area. The result is a torque that turns the front wheel towards the lean. Bicycles are designed to accentuate the effect, by using trail and center of mass of the whole steering system, but those are embellishments hit upon by trial and error, not what keeps it up. What keeps a bicycle upright is the same principle that keeps a train on it's tracks.

I find it unconvincing that the tire/ground contact point being behind the steering axis has a significant balancing effect.  While it obviously does steer the wheel correctly to promote balance, if the bicycle is stationary, I am unconvinced that it does the same thing when the bicycle is moving.  The traction friction of the tire on the ground, as the bicycle is steering while moving forward, acts in the opposite direction as when the bicycle is leaning over and stationary.  It is gravity that makes the wheel steer left if you tilt a stationary bicycle left, because the weight is supported by a part of the tire that is behind the steering axis...  but while a bicycle is moving forward, inertia opposes any steering acceleration, and would cause a centripetal force that would try to steer the wheel in the opposite direction as gravity tries to make it turn (so if it was steering left, the friction on the ground would try to turn the wheel to the right, which would cause the bike to fall over).  It seems apparent to me that the caster effect would not promote balance while the bicycle is moving.  I think the gyroscopic precession, which is strong and turns the front wheel to correct leaning, is the real prime balancing force.
I don't understand why anyone says that scientists don't know why bicycles balance by themselves...  It is too intuitively obvious.

a combination of geometry and material properties. when a tire is in contact, it deforms to make a contact patch. the shape of that patch is determined by the force on the tire and the tires resistance to deformation as well as the angle the tire is in contact with the ground on. when the contact angle is not 90 degrees, the contact patch is not symmetrical and the effective radius of the tire changes (same concept as a train steering with a locked axle).

-when the contact patch is larger on one side than the other (like when the bike is leaning), more drag is felt on the lower side, steering the tire into the turn (rolling resistance and deformation of the tire)
-when the radius of the tire is changed, the middle still moves the same distance per revolution but the inside travels less, steering the wheel and imparting a force towards the direction that the bike is falling. (this concept can be noticed if you ride a bike along a side hill, try and go straight and you find yourself turning up the hill unless you counter steer)

what is happening is as the bike starts to fall/lean, the friction the tires feel is increased. the bikes forward momentum is converted into movement that counters the pull of gravity and keeps the bike upright until it slows down. the bike is riding the path of least resistance. having wheel caster and the gyroscopic effects add to the stability but are minor forces.

so, like with the lopsided spinning disk (veritasium), its friction that makes things work as they do.

I think it's rather obvious that velocity, weight, and friction play a large part in keeping bikes upright.

If a bike is at a stand still or moving too slowly, it will simply fall over. There is nothing you can do to stop this. (We're assuming your bike is in an open space)

Add weight to the seat of the bike, and the velocity required to keep the bike upright changes. The more weight added increases the velocity required to keep the bike upright.

Of course, if you have no rubber tires on your bike, it will react quite differently to each set of terrain. Assuming we have rubber tires, the treads on the tires also effect how the bike reacts on certain terrain. Assuming you have a dirt bike, you'll have to exert more force on the pedals to make the bike move faster on something like pavement.

All these factors come together to determine what is needed to keep a bike standing upright.
Of course, there are other variables, such as bike design, but the video explains it nicely.

The physics of the bike are actually quite simple. The torque of the wheels create thrust that propels the bike forward. When the bike tips over, the CoM and CoT become out of line and the CoT causes the bike to spin. The resulting centrifugal force pushes the bike upright. This is why you can nearly touch the ground with your leg on a bike, but the bike miraculously rights itself.

On a forward rolling tire, the area of rubber that is about to roll onto the ground is heavier than the bike starting to tilt to the side and so, with the help of enough speed, the area about to roll onto the ground falls first and has to fall forward (on the centre, the heaviest part of the tire), propping the bike up on top of the tires, more of an accessory or add-on of the tire rather than the bulk of the tire or bicycle. That is why it is more stable to go faster. The falling front area of the tire seems to become heavier. The next area falls on top of the next and it is kind of like there is no friction (as usual with wheels). This is my hypothesis that is solely based on tuition. I haven't weighed anything or measured speeds to know the heavier force.

Centrifugal force, the last piece of the puzzle?

Not finding the centrifugal force treated in the otherwise excellent review of bicycle dynamics in the video “How do bikes stay up?” at 

 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZAc5t2lkvo    was a great surprise.

Consider for example what you automatically do if you begin to lean to one side or the other while riding a bike: you simply steer in that direction (!) for regaining your upright position.

And, right after escaping an impending mishap and returning to the vertical, albeit slightly off course, your body is usually already moving sideways in the other direction, forcing you to steer back in that direction in order to continue the ride as intended. 

The need for continuous corrections in the outlined fashion explains why a bicycle trace (in snow for instance) is always more or less wobbly, and in particular so when riding at low speed. In essence then, successfully riding on two wheels in tandem is simply a matter of forever delaying an otherwise imminent accident by utilizing our sense of balance. 

The required correcting forces are generated as long as we follow a suitably curved trajectory at sufficient speed. Smaller curve radii produce greater force. Greater speed is even more efficient as regards force magnitude. Considerable forces may be acting here.

As an example, let’s make the following assumptions:

d = 10 deg.           deviation from vertical (slightly exaggerated in the diagram below)
G = 9.81 m/s^2     acceleration of gravity
m = 75 kg             body mass of cyclist (mass of bike disregarded here forsimplicity)
v = 5 m/s              velocity (18 km/h)

                                         
      
       m x G x tan(d) < --------  m  -------- > (m x v^2)/r    counteracting centrifugal force
                                                | \
                                                |   \
                                                |     \           Vector diagram showing relevant forces
                                                |       \          when the bike rider leans to the left, 
                                                |   d    \        and steers to the left!
                                                |           \
                                                |             \
                                               \/              \
                                            m x G            .                
                                                                    .
                                                                      .
                                                                        .
                                                                          .
                                                                      -------- supporting point (the road)
                                                                      /////////

The diagram indicates that if the two horizontal forces balance exactly, the ride could go on forever with the rider leaning to left and following a circular path. The radius of that special path is given by 

m x G x tan(d) = (m x v^2)/r     or

r = ( v^2) / (G x tan(d)) 

By plugging in the assumed values we get

r = ( 5^2) / (9.81 x tan(10)) = 25/(9.81 x 0.176) = 14.5 meters

The counteracting centrifugal force in this case will be

 Fc = (m x v^2)/r = (75 x 5^2)/14.5 = 75 x 25/14.5 = 129 N 

This corresponds to about 13.2 kg or nearly 18 % of the riders body mass. 

Already here it should be rather obvious that if safe riding is to be expected, the centrifugal force must not be canceled out. 

We get out of a curved path when riding a bike by briefly steering even more into the curve, i. e. by making the curve radius slightly smaller. This over-steering will generate a small surplus of centrifugal force, that will then gently accelerate the body mass towards the vertical, and this process finally allows us to gradually steer out of the curve.

How much will the handlebar need to be turned in this case? The figure below with 

a = angle of front-wheel turn (exaggerated in the figure below)
r = curve radius as before
s = distance between wheels, typically 1.1 meters

gives an idea.
                                                                                      \
                                                                                   .    \      Front wheel    ----
                                                                       .               .  \                           .
                                                           .                           .                              .
                                               .                                       .                              s 
                                    .                                                  .                              .
                        .                    a                                        |                               .
              .         .           .          .           .           .          .    |        Rear wheel     -- 
                                                                                       | 
                                              r

From s = r x tan(a) we get
 
a = arctan(s/r) = arctan(1.1/14.5) = 4.3 degrees 

On a regular “straight-line” trajectory, the correcting handlebar turns will be much smaller.


From the previous analysis follows that any bike given sufficient speed will be able to ride itself as long as it is self-steering in the usual fashion (entering into a suitably curved path after tilting). 

Of all real forces, only friction between wheels and ground, gravity and the centrifugal force appear to be essential for this remarkable behavior to be possible.

The total castor of the front wheel of a bicycle is due to a) the rake angle multiplied by wheel radius (geometric castor),  b) the castor distance of the axle behind the steering axis (mechanical castor) and c) the flexibility of the pneumatic tire developing side forces behind its center of footprint (pneumatic castor). These are all stabilizing although often on a bicycle the mechanical castor is deliberately made negative in order to provide a better response to deliberate steering action.

As an engineer who worked in nose-wheel shimmy of aircraft, I find this video to be excellent in explaining bike stability.The gyro effect is probably the strongest for high speeds and so on the Bloodhound project there is probably good stability, provided the ability for the wheels to steer is not limited by making them too rigid on their axles. The equations for this stability are determinate (using a linearizing assumption) and unlike what was shown at the end of the video, it is not a mystery and this stability can be exactly determined. The problems start for non-linear displacements due to uneven ground, when simulation should be used to decide the permissible worst sized obstacle.

The three moments to steer the front wheel are not significant. The location of the center of mass can be on either side of the axis as long as it doesn't create a high moment of inertia as was done here. The normal force has no effect as it is canceled by the camber force and the gyroscopic moment is not large enough. If you treat the problem as a dynamic problem instead of looking for static causes it becomes quickly obvious. The steering moment that causes a bike to self correct is actually due to the rear slip angle force which opposes the camber force at the rear wheel while the camber force at the front wheel is free to yaw the bike into the direction it would fall.

Note that gyroscopic effect is a reaction to a roll torque. Once the wheel has steered inwards enough to produce a coordinated turn, the roll torque and the related gyroscopic effect become zero. As the wheel continues to steer inwards enough to start reducing (correcting) the lean angle to return to vertical, the roll torque becomes outwards, and the gyroscopic reaction opposes (dampens) the inwards steering needed for correction back to vertical. So the net gyroscopic effect is to dampen (oppose) the steering correction related to bike geometry.

That helicopter physics video you reference is very wrong. Yes, gyroscopic precession exists, but it's not what's responsible for the ~90° phase lag in cyclic input and aircraft response in a helicopter's rotor. The blades flap up in down roughly in resonance with the rotor rotation (in the case of small hinge offsets). Resonant systems have a characteristic 90 lag, and the blade will flap up 90 degrees after the max cyclic input and down 90 degrees after the min cyclic input. This flapping tilts the tip path plane, which effectively tilts the lift vector, applying a lateral or longitudinal force above the CG, creating a pitching or rolling moment, which changes the aircraft's attitude.

In this explanation you point out that the surface force acts outward. Isn't this wrong?? When the bike tilts to one side the wheels have a tendency of slipping in the outward direction and hence the force of friction should act inward. This is what provides the centripetal force necessary for making the turn.Hence the surface force must act inwards.

BTW your animation is slightly wrong as for a forward moving- self riding bike the pedals can't rotate :).

Actually a bike is not that efficient. It uses about 300W for a 70+20kg (biker+bike) in 25km/h, its about 12Wh/km for 90kg. That´s about 135Wh/km for 1 ton.

Compare that to a car that uses about 150Wh/km for the total vehicle and its about 1.5ton, that is only 100Wh/km. So a car is actually more efficient than a bike, kg for kg, And that in much higher speeds.

Also, can compare with Shell super-miler competition they are 10 times more efficient then bikes, about the same wight and still run faster.

Also, a moving bike with locked handle bars will not fall as quick as a stationary one. The reason for this is gyroscopic force. At sleepwalking this effect is mineskule, but already at biking speed, about 25km/h is already quite high.

"The gryoscopic force dont make the bike stand up"
This is partial wrong. Its true that it don´t make the bike stand up, but it slow down the fall.
That the gyroscopic force change the angle 90 degree is only true for the front wheel.. The back wheel that is locked in place it will make it harder for the wheel to tip over.

"Sicentist dont know"
This is just stupid: The science is quite clear. Is rather a mater of math how much amount of what you need for different combination. By "dont know, that we have not precalculated every possible scenario, well that is true. But we can pre calculate.

Then also, in real life, there is always a margin of error. If you are to close to the margine of error you can´t be sure if it works or not, but is not the same as we don´t know... Rather, we actually do know that there is a specific margin of error.

These videos are informative but always lack key information or explanations.
In the case of this particular video, you didn't explain the whole "the bike rides under the center of mass and regains balance" thing. What do you mean by "rides under the center of mass"? I didn't understand it on your SciShow Talkshow and I didn't understand it now. I can try and guess what you mean based on what I see but I don't understand it as a whole. Maybe it would have been easier if you showed us the center of mass of the whole bike.
The other problem appears when you talk about the inclined angle of the front wheel axis. You compare the inclined axis of the wheel with a line that would be at 90°. The problem is that you don't really explain what that line is. At first I thought it was what the axis would look like if it wasn't inclined, but the line doesn't even pass through the center of the wheel. It is just a chord of the circle that is the wheel. Then I thought that it could have been misplaced, but then the axis would not touch the ground behind that line at a right angle.
